elements.content: The room-temperature solution reactions of R- or S-H2opa (H2opa = 2-hydroxy-2-phenylacetic acid) with freshly prepared [Ag(NH3)2](OH) in the presence of 1,3-di(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp) yielded two enantiomeric compounds, [Ag2(R-Hopa)(bpp)2](R-Hopa)·3H2O (1·3H2O) and [Ag2(S-Hopa)(bpp)2](S-Hopa)·3H2O (2·3H2O). While a similar solution reaction was carried out with racemic H2opa instead of R- or S-H2opa, a racemic compound [Ag2(R-Hopa)(S-Hopa)(bpp)2]·4H2O (3·4H2O) was formed. When bulk crystals of 3·4H2O were exposed to the air at ambient temperature, a partially dehydrated compound [Ag2(R-Hopa)(S-Hopa)(bpp)2]·H2O (4·H2O) was found, which would transform to [Ag2(R-Hopa)(S-Hopa)(bpp)2]·2MeOH (5·2MeOH) by exposing the crystals of 4·H2O in mixed MeOH−EtOH−DMF solvent or in methanol. Compounds 1−5 have characteristic hydrogen-bonding-directed sandwich-like networks consisting of Ag−bpp layers and Hopa−−ROH chains (R = H for 1−4 and Me for 5). The different structural features come from different hydrogen bonding interactions between Hopa− and the lattice water or MeOH molecules. In 1·3H2O and 2·3H2O, R-Hopa− or S-Hopa− form left-handed or right-handed helices with water molecules running in parallel to the Ag-bpp layers while in 3·4H2O, the centrosymmetric hydrogen bonding chains are composed of two enantiomers of Hopa−. Upon dehydration, the Ag···Ag dimeric units in [Ag2(bpp)2] n 2n+ in 3·4H2O were broken and the positions of the Ag-bpp chains were adjusted to form new Hopa−−H2O chains between the silver layers. After absorbing methanol, the Ag-bpp chains restored to their original layer structures and 5·2MeOH is pseudopolymorphic to 3·4H2O. The reversible dehydration, readsorption, and guest-exchange among 3·4H2O, 4·H2O, and 5·2MeOH is an interesting example of phase transformation for racemic coordination polymers. The chirality of 1·3H2O and 2·3H2O was further conformed by solid-state CD spectra.

elements.content: Five new sandwich-like coordination polymers based on [Ag2(bpp)2] n 2n+ layers (bpp = 1,3-di(4-pyridyl)propane) and [(Hopa)2(ROH) x ] n 2n− helices (R = H or Me; x = 1, 2 and 4; H2opa = 2-hydroxy-2-phenylacetic acid) have been successfully synthesized from freshly prepared [Ag(NH3)2](OH) with chiral or racemic H2opa and bpp. The reversible phase transformations in racemic coordination polymers by partial dehydration, readsorption, and selective guest-exchange were observed.
elements.clean_text: Five new sandwich-like coordination polymers based on [Ag2(bpp)2] n  2n+ layers (bpp = 1,3-di(4-pyridyl)propane) and [(Hopa)2(ROH) x ] n  2n- helices (R = H or Me; x = 1, 2 and 4; H2opa = 2-hydroxy-2-phenylacetic acid) have been successfully synthesized from freshly prepared [Ag(NH3)2](OH) with chiral or racemic H2opa and bpp. The reversible phase transformations in racemic coordination polymers by partial dehydration, readsorption, and selective guest-exchange were observed.

elements.content: Recent interest in crystalline homochiral materials is rapidly expanding because of their potential applications in enantioselective separation and synthesis. Homochiral crystalline materials can be obtained through chiral synthesis using enantiomerically pure precursors, or by the resolution of racemic mixtures. Recently, a chiral induction effect has been developed as an effective method to introduce chirality into materials. Under certain circumstances, enantiopure crystalline compounds can be produced spontaneously. Nevertheless, the mechanism of spontaneous resolution and the formation of chiral frameworks have not been fully understood. Intensive study of the crystallization of chiral materials from enantiopure or racemic ligands is thus necessary for the rational design of homochiral materials.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Recent interest in crystalline homochiral materials is rapidly expanding because of their potential applications in enantioselective separation and synthesis. Homochiral crystalline materials can be obtained through chiral synthesis using enantiomerically pure precursors, or by the resolution of racemic mixtures. Recently, a chiral induction effect has been developed as an effective method to introduce chirality into materials. Under certain circumstances, enantiopure crystalline compounds can be produced spontaneously. Nevertheless, the mechanism of spontaneous resolution and the formation of chiral frameworks have not been fully understood. Intensive study of the crystallization of chiral materials from enantiopure or racemic ligands is thus necessary for the rational design of homochiral materials.

elements.content: Phase transformation based on flexible networks is one of the most interesting phenomena in coordination polymers, which has attracted considerable attention in recent years because the transformation process can provide some clues to reveal the relationship between structures and properties involved. However, single crystal-to-single crystal (SC-SC) transformations are still a challenge since crystals can hardly retain their crystallinity after dramatic solid-state rearrangement of the molecules. A number of metal organic framework (MOF) SC-SC transformations in the process of guest desorption-resorption, guest-exchange, ligand exchange and thermally induced rearrangement reactions have been reported. Sandwich-like networks have the potential to be such a kind of dynamic material as they may sustain the changes caused by external stimuli either within the layer or between the layers.

A number of metal organic framework (MOF) SC-SC transformations in the process of guest desorption-resorption, guest-exchange, ligand exchange and thermally induced rearrangement reactions have been reported. Sandwich-like networks have the potential to be such a kind of dynamic material as they may sustain the changes caused by external stimuli either within the layer or between the layers.

elements.content: We have previously reported some silver(I)-dipyridyl-carboxylate compounds, which have typical 3D supramolecular networks constructed from Ag···Ag interaction directed [Ag(N−N)] n n+ coordination ladders or layers linked by carboxylate pillars. As an extension of our study, chiral or racemic 2-hydroxy-2-phenylacetic acid (H2opa) was introduced into the reaction system. Here we report the synthesis and structures of three silver(I)-dipyridyl-carboxylate compounds with chiral and racemic sandwich-like network structures as well as their phase transformation behavior via selective guest-exchange. Room temperature solution reactions of freshly prepared [Ag(NH3)2](OH) with R- or S-2-hydroxy-2-phenylacetic acid (H2opa) and 1,3-di(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp) in a 1:1:1 molar ratio yielded a pair of enantiomeric coordination networks, [Ag2(R-Hopa)(bpp)2](R-Hopa)·3H2O (1·3H2O) and [Ag2(S-Hopa)(bpp)2](S-Hopa)·3H2O (2·3H2O), respectively. Racemic compound [Ag2(R-Hopa)(S-Hopa)(bpp)2]·4H2O (3·4H2O) was formed from a similar solution reaction when racemic H2opa was used instead. Two derived phases, [Ag2(R-Hopa)(S-Hopa)(bpp)2]·H2O (4·H2O) and [Ag2(R-Hopa)(S-Hopa)(bpp)2]·2MeOH (5·2MeOH), were obtained from 3·4H2O via partial dehydration, reabsorption, and guest-exchange process.

elements.content: The reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as received without further purification. The C, H, and N microanalyses were carried out with Elementar Vario-EL CHNS elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr tablets in the range of 4000−400 cm−1 on a Bio-Rad FTS-7 spectrometer. Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was performed at a rate of 10 °C/min under N2 using a NETZSCH TG 209 system. The solid-state (KCl pellets) circular dichroism (CD) spectra were recorded on a JASCO J-810 spectropolarimeter.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

The reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as received without further purification. The C, H, and N microanalyses were carried out with Elementar Vario-EL CHNS elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr tablets in the range of 4000-400 cm-1 on a Bio-Rad FTS-7 spectrometer. Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was performed at a rate of 10 °C/min under N2 using a NETZSCH TG 209 system. The solid-state (KCl pellets) circular dichroism (CD) spectra were recorded on a JASCO J-810 spectropolarimeter.

R-H2opa (0.061 g, 0.4 mmol) and bpp (0.079 g, 0.4 mmol) were slowly added to the silver solution. The mixture was further vigorously stirred under heating at 50 °C for 2 h. The resulting solution was filtered and allowed to stand in air at room temperature. Block colorless crystals of 1·3H2O were obtained after four days (yields 0.068 g, ca. 35%). elements.content: Data collections were performed on Oxford Gemini S Ultra diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å) at 150 K for 1 and on Bruker Apex CCD diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 150(2) or 293(2) K for 2−5. The intensities were integrated with SAINT+, which were also applied corrections for Lorentz and polarization effects. Absorption corrections were applied by using the multiscan program SADABS. The structures were solved by direct methods. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by least-squares method on F 2 using the SHELXTL program. The organic hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically (Caryl−H 0.93 Å; Calkyl−H 0.97 Å); the aqua hydrogen atoms were located from difference maps and refined with isotropic temperature factors. Crystal data as well as details of data collection and refinements for compounds 1−5 are summarized in Table . Selected bond distances are listed in Tables and . Hydrogen bond distances and angles are listed in Tables −.

X-Ray Crystallography

Data collections were performed on Oxford Gemini S Ultra diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å) at 150 K for 1 and on Bruker Apex CCD diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 150(2) or 293(2) K for 2-5. The intensities were integrated with SAINT+, which were also applied corrections for Lorentz and polarization effects. Absorption corrections were applied by using the multiscan program SADABS. The structures were solved by direct methods. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by least-squares method on F 2 using the SHELXTL program. The organic hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically (Caryl-H 0.93 Å; Calkyl-H 0.97 Å); the aqua hydrogen atoms were located from difference maps and refined with isotropic temperature factors. Crystal data as well as details of data collection and refinements for compounds 1-5 are summarized in Table . Selected bond distances are listed in Tables  and . Hydrogen bond distances and angles are listed in Tables -.

It is well-known that different sources of the reactant components, for example, the utilization of many metal salts or using various organic precursors instead of the target ligands, have great influence on the resulted products. The reactions of silver(I) salts and organic ligands with carboxylic groups in aqueous solution often lead to microcrystalline or amorphous insoluble ‘silver complexes’, which is presumably due to the formation of polymeric structures via rapid interactions between carboxylic groups and silver ions. There is still a general challenge in growing single crystals of desired materials with suitable size for X-ray structural analysis. Controlled release of silver ions may help to slow down the formation of silver-organic coordination frameworks and grow better single crystals. For example, Mak and co-workers used various zwitterionic betaine ligands to yield a number of polymeric silver(I) carboxylates compounds. Smith and co-workers obtained a series of Ag multicarboxylate compounds from ammonia solutions and Michaelides and co-workers reported a novel succinatodisilver(I) complex prepared via gel permeation method. We have used freshly synthesized [Ag(NH3)2](OH) to react with multicarboxylic acid ligands, such as 1,2,3,4,5,6-cyclohexanehexacarboxylic acid and 1,3,5-cyclohexanetricarboxylic acid, and successfully obtained some interesting polymeric coordination compounds. In this study, we fixed the molar ratio of [Ag(NH3)2](OH)/H2opa/bpp to 1:1:1 and investigated how the chirality of H2opa ligands impacts on supramolecular architectures of the Ag−Hopa−−bpp system. As expected, 1·3H2O, 2·3H2O, and 3·4H2O were obtained from the room-temperature solution reactions of freshly prepared [Ag(NH3)2](OH), R-H2opa (or S-H2opa or rac-H2opa) and bpp in a 1:1:1 molar ratio. As these reactions were carried out at ambient temperature under mild reaction conditions, the racemization of the chiral H2opa ligands, which might happen at high temperatures as reported, could be efficiently avoided.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

It is well-known that different sources of the reactant components, for example, the utilization of many metal salts or using various organic precursors instead of the target ligands, have great influence on the resulted products. The reactions of silver(I) salts and organic ligands with carboxylic groups in aqueous solution often lead to microcrystalline or amorphous insoluble ‘silver complexes', which is presumably due to the formation of polymeric structures via rapid interactions between carboxylic groups and silver ions. There is still a general challenge in growing single crystals of desired materials with suitable size for X-ray structural analysis. Controlled release of silver ions may help to slow down the formation of silver-organic coordination frameworks and grow better single crystals. For example, Mak and co-workers used various zwitterionic betaine ligands to yield a number of polymeric silver(I) carboxylates compounds. Smith and co-workers obtained a series of Ag multicarboxylate compounds from ammonia solutions and Michaelides and co-workers reported a novel succinatodisilver(I) complex prepared via gel permeation method. We have used freshly synthesized [Ag(NH3)2](OH) to react with multicarboxylic acid ligands, such as 1,2,3,4,5,6-cyclohexanehexacarboxylic acid and 1,3,5-cyclohexanetricarboxylic acid, and successfully obtained some interesting polymeric coordination compounds. In this study, we fixed the molar ratio of [Ag(NH3)2](OH)/H2opa/bpp to 1:1:1 and investigated how the chirality of H2opa ligands impacts on supramolecular architectures of the Ag-Hopa--bpp system. As expected, 1⋅3H2O, 2⋅3H2O, and 3⋅4H2O were obtained from the room-temperature solution reactions of freshly prepared [Ag(NH3)2](OH), R-H2opa (or S-H2opa or rac-H2opa) and bpp in a 1:1:1 molar ratio. As these reactions were carried out at ambient temperature under mild reaction conditions, the racemization of the chiral H2opa ligands, which might happen at high temperatures as reported, could be efficiently avoided.

elements.content: The crystals of 1·3H2O and 2·3H2O lost crystallinity after exposed in air for several days. Comparatively, the bulky sample of 3·4H2O slowly transformed to the partially dehydrated compound 4·H2O when exposed in air at ambient temperature for about one month. 4·H2O has a much smaller unit cell in triclinic space P1̅ and is apparently a more condensed phase than 3·4H2O. The phase transformation between 3·4H2O and 4·H2O is reversible and when 4·H2O was soaked in aqueous solution for two weeks, crystalline 3·4H2O was yielded.
elements.clean_text:
Phase Transformation among 3⋅4H2O, 4⋅H2O, and 5⋅2MeOH via Partial Dehydration, Readsorption, and Guest-Exchange

The crystals of 1⋅3H2O and 2⋅3H2O lost crystallinity after exposed in air for several days. Comparatively, the bulky sample of 3⋅4H2O slowly transformed to the partially dehydrated compound 4⋅H2O when exposed in air at ambient temperature for about one month. 4⋅H2O has a much smaller unit cell in triclinic space P1̅ and is apparently a more condensed phase than 3⋅4H2O. The phase transformation between 3⋅4H2O and 4⋅H2O is reversible and when 4⋅H2O was soaked in aqueous solution for two weeks, crystalline 3⋅4H2O was yielded.

elements.content: Crystals of 5·2MeOH were obtained by exposing the crystals of 4·H2O in MeOH for one week or in mixed MeOH−EtOH−DMF solvent. Single crystal X-ray crystallography shows that 5·2MeOH has almost the same unit cell and the same space group as 3·4H2O, suggesting that 3·4H2O and 5·2MeOH have similar coordination networks and supramolecular packing. After absorbing two methanol molecules per formula, the condensed framework of 4·H2O changed back to the phase with larger void space. It is interesting that 4·H2O can also be formed again when bulky 5·2MeOH was exposed to wet air at ambient temperature for one week. The processes above can be monitored by single crystal and powder X-ray diffraction. The schematic representation of the reactions, dehydration, readsorption, and guest-exchange were summarized in Scheme .
elements.clean_text: Crystals of 5⋅2MeOH were obtained by exposing the crystals of 4⋅H2O in MeOH for one week or in mixed MeOH-EtOH-DMF solvent. Single crystal X-ray crystallography shows that 5⋅2MeOH has almost the same unit cell and the same space group as 3⋅4H2O, suggesting that 3⋅4H2O and 5⋅2MeOH have similar coordination networks and supramolecular packing. After absorbing two methanol molecules per formula, the condensed framework of 4⋅H2O changed back to the phase with larger void space. It is interesting that 4⋅H2O can also be formed again when bulky 5⋅2MeOH was exposed to wet air at ambient temperature for one week. The processes above can be monitored by single crystal and powder X-ray diffraction. The schematic representation of the reactions, dehydration, readsorption, and guest-exchange were summarized in Scheme .

elements.content: 1·3H2O and 2·3H2O are enantiomers. Each asymmetric unit contains one dimeric [Ag2(bpp)2]2+ cation, one coordinated and one free Hopa− anion (R-Hopa in 1·3H2O and S-Hopa in 2·3H2O), and three guest water molecules. All the Ag(I) ions have the T-shaped coordination geometry surrounded by two nitrogen atoms from two bpp ligands and one weakly coordinated carboxylate group from R-Hopa− or S-Hopa− (Figure a,b).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures

Structures of [Ag2(R-Hopa)(bpp)2](R-Hopa)⋅3H2O (1⋅3H2O) and [Ag2(S-Hopa)(bpp)2](S-Hopa)⋅3H2O (2⋅3H2O)

 1⋅3H2O and 2⋅3H2O are enantiomers. Each asymmetric unit contains one dimeric [Ag2(bpp)2]2+ cation, one coordinated and one free Hopa- anion (R-Hopa in 1⋅3H2O and S-Hopa in 2⋅3H2O), and three guest water molecules. All the Ag(I) ions have the T-shaped coordination geometry surrounded by two nitrogen atoms from two bpp ligands and one weakly coordinated carboxylate group from R-Hopa- or S-Hopa- (Figure a,b).

elements.content: In 1·3H2O, two crystallographically distinctive Ag atoms, Ag1 and Ag2, are linked by two bpp ligands [Ag1−N = 2.168(4) and 2.172(4) Å, Ag2−N = 2.137(4) and 2.147(4) Å] and form an infinite [Ag(bpp)] n chain along the c axis. The adjacent Ag-bpp chains are aligned in parallel and bridged into a 2D coordination layer by carboxylate groups from Hopa− [Ag1−O1 = 2.584(3) Å, Ag2−O2 = 2.664(6) Å]. The Ag···Ag separation is 2.986(1) Å (Figure c), much shorter than van der Waals radii of two silver ions (3.44 Å). The Hopa− ligands stand alternatively on both sides of the coordination layer along the silver-pyridine chains. Notably, the coordinated Hopa− on the [Ag2(bpp)2]2+ dimer on adjacent silver-pyridine chains extend in the same direction and form 1D hydrogen-bonded helical with the free R-Hopa− and lattice water molecules along the a-axis between the layers. Each helical step contains one coordinated and one lattice R-Hopa− anion linked by two water molecules with the pitch of 8.811(1) Å [O2W···O2 = 2.772(6) Å, O2W−H2WA···O2 = 163(6)°; O3W···O1 = 2.776(6) Å, O3W−H3WB···O1 = 156(6)°; O3W···O2W = 2.771(7) Å, O3W−H3WA···O2W = 176(6)°] (Figure d,e). All the hydrogen-bonded R-Hopa− helices are left-handed (M). The adjacent 2D [Ag2(bpp)2] n 2n+ layers are interconnected with a distance of 9.0 Å by the left-handed hydrogen-bonded helices and the third aqua molecules [O1W···O3a = 2.902(6) Å, O1W−H1WB···O3a = 173(7)°; O1W···Ag1 = 2.879 Å, O1W···Ag2 = 3.044 Å] into a chiral sandwich-like supramolecular network in the space group P21 (Flack parameter: −0.008(6)).
elements.clean_text: In 1⋅3H2O, two crystallographically distinctive Ag atoms, Ag1 and Ag2, are linked by two bpp ligands [Ag1-N = 2.168(4) and 2.172(4) Å, Ag2-N = 2.137(4) and 2.147(4) Å] and form an infinite [Ag(bpp)] n  chain along the c axis. The adjacent Ag-bpp chains are aligned in parallel and bridged into a 2D coordination layer by carboxylate groups from Hopa- [Ag1-O1 = 2.584(3) Å, Ag2-O2 = 2.664(6) Å]. The Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag separation is 2.986(1) Å (Figure c), much shorter than van der Waals radii of two silver ions (3.44 Å). The Hopa- ligands stand alternatively on both sides of the coordination layer along the silver-pyridine chains. Notably, the coordinated Hopa- on the [Ag2(bpp)2]2+ dimer on adjacent silver-pyridine chains extend in the same direction and form 1D hydrogen-bonded helical with the free R-Hopa- and lattice water molecules along the a-axis between the layers. Each helical step contains one coordinated and one lattice R-Hopa- anion linked by two water molecules with the pitch of 8.811(1) Å [O2W⋅⋅⋅O2 = 2.772(6) Å, O2W-H2WA⋅⋅⋅O2 = 163(6)°; O3W⋅⋅⋅O1 = 2.776(6) Å, O3W-H3WB⋅⋅⋅O1 = 156(6)°; O3W⋅⋅⋅O2W = 2.771(7) Å, O3W-H3WA⋅⋅⋅O2W = 176(6)°] (Figure d,e). All the hydrogen-bonded R-Hopa- helices are left-handed (M). The adjacent 2D [Ag2(bpp)2] n  2n+ layers are interconnected with a distance of 9.0 Å by the left-handed hydrogen-bonded helices and the third aqua molecules [O1W⋅⋅⋅O3a = 2.902(6) Å, O1W-H1WB⋅⋅⋅O3a = 173(7)°; O1W⋅⋅⋅Ag1 = 2.879 Å, O1W⋅⋅⋅Ag2 = 3.044 Å] into a chiral sandwich-like supramolecular network in the space group P21 (Flack parameter: -0.008(6)).

elements.content: In contrast to 1·3H2O, 1D right-handed (P) homochiral helical chains are found in 2·3H2O [O2W···O2 = 2.765(3) Å, O2W−H2WA···O2 = 159(4)°; O3W···O2W = 2.774(4) Å, O3W−H3WB···O2W = 174(4)°; O3W···O1 = 2.778(4) Å, O3W−H3WA···O1 = 169(5)°] (Figure f,g). The right-handedness of the helical obviously originates from the opposite chirality of S-Hopa−. The corresponding geometric parameters [Ag1−N = 2.165(3) and 2.171(3) Å, Ag1−O = 2.582(2) Å; Ag1···Ag2 = 2.9835(3) Å] in 2·3H2O are similar to 1·3H2O. Weak interactions between Ag(I) and water oxygen atoms [O1W···Ag1 = 2.880 Å, O1W···Ag2 = 3.040 Å] connect the right-handed hydrogen-bonded helices and achiral [Ag2(bpp)2] n 2n+ layers to generate a chiral sandwich-like network in a chiral space group P21 and with absolute structure parameter of −0.06 (1).
elements.clean_text: In contrast to 1⋅3H2O, 1D right-handed (P) homochiral helical chains are found in 2⋅3H2O [O2W⋅⋅⋅O2 = 2.765(3) Å, O2W-H2WA⋅⋅⋅O2 = 159(4)°; O3W⋅⋅⋅O2W = 2.774(4) Å, O3W-H3WB⋅⋅⋅O2W = 174(4)°; O3W⋅⋅⋅O1 = 2.778(4) Å, O3W-H3WA⋅⋅⋅O1 = 169(5)°] (Figure f,g). The right-handedness of the helical obviously originates from the opposite chirality of S-Hopa-. The corresponding geometric parameters [Ag1-N = 2.165(3) and 2.171(3) Å, Ag1-O = 2.582(2) Å; Ag1⋅⋅⋅Ag2 = 2.9835(3) Å] in 2⋅3H2O are similar to 1⋅3H2O. Weak interactions between Ag(I) and water oxygen atoms [O1W⋅⋅⋅Ag1 = 2.880 Å, O1W⋅⋅⋅Ag2 = 3.040 Å] connect the right-handed hydrogen-bonded helices and achiral [Ag2(bpp)2] n  2n+ layers to generate a chiral sandwich-like network in a chiral space group P21 and with absolute structure parameter of -0.06 (1).

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray crystallographic analysis reveals that 3·4H2O crystallizes in the space group of P21/c. The overall network is very similar to chiral 1·3H2O, which is composed of the 2D [Ag2(bpp)2] n 2n+ layers and Hopa−−H2O helices (Figure a). The asymmetric unit contains one silver cation, one bpp in all-trans-conformation, one Hopa− anion, and two guest water molecules. Ag1 is in a heavily distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry surrounded by two bpp ligands and one weakly chelated carboxylate group from Hopa− [Ag1−N = 2.166(3) and 2.179(3) Å, Ag1−O = 2.644(4) and 2.673(3) Å]. The adjacent [Ag(bpp)] n chains are linked into a 2D layer by unsupported Ag···Ag interactions in the distance of 3.223(1) Å, longer than those found in 1·3H2O and 2·3H2O (Figure b).

Structure of [Ag2(R-Hopa)(S-Hopa)(bpp)2]⋅4H2O (3⋅4H2O)

Single crystal X-ray crystallographic analysis reveals that 3⋅4H2O crystallizes in the space group of P21/c. The overall network is very similar to chiral 1⋅3H2O, which is composed of the 2D [Ag2(bpp)2] n  2n+ layers and Hopa--H2O helices (Figure a). The asymmetric unit contains one silver cation, one bpp in all-trans-conformation, one Hopa- anion, and two guest water molecules. Ag1 is in a heavily distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry surrounded by two bpp ligands and one weakly chelated carboxylate group from Hopa- [Ag1-N = 2.166(3) and 2.179(3) Å, Ag1-O = 2.644(4) and 2.673(3) Å]. The adjacent [Ag(bpp)] n  chains are linked into a 2D layer by unsupported Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag interactions in the distance of 3.223(1) Å, longer than those found in 1⋅3H2O and 2⋅3H2O (Figure b).

elements.content: Though the crystal structure of racemic 3·4H2O is very similar to chiral 1·3H2O and 2·3H2O in connectivity, successive [Ag(bpp)] n n+ chains within the layer are inversion-related and thus contain alternating enantiomers of the Hopa−. The R- and S-Hopa−, along with four lattice aqua molecules, form Hopa−−H2O hydrogen bonding chains along the b-axis [O3···O1a = 2.894(6) Å, O3−H3···O1a = 154.4°; O2W···O2 = 2.753(7) Å, O2W−H2WA···O2 = 148.8°; O1W···O2 Wb = 2.79 (1) Å, O1W−H1WB···O2 Wb = 159(5)°; O1W···O1 = 2.74(1) Å, O1W−H1WA···O1 = 175(7)°]. Each step of the chain is 8.883(2) Å (Figure c). The nonchiral Hopa−−H2O chains, replacing either left-handed in 1·3H2O or right-handed helices in 2·3H2O, are arranged in parallel to link the [Ag2(bpp)2] n 2n+ layers into a three-dimensional supramolecular network.

elements.content: Interestingly, the hydroxyl group on the Hopa− ligand is disordered on two positions at 50%:50% possibility, that is, 50% R-Hopa− and 50% S-Hopa− are found to coordinate to the silver atom in each asymmetric unit. Considering the existence of inversion centers on between two Hopa− within the hydrogen bonding chains and between the Ag···Ag dimers, two enantiomers form nonchiral Hopa−−H2O chains, which have mirror symmetry to each other, in a statistically 1:1 ratio (Figure d).

elements.content: As 4·H2O was yielded from the dehydration of 3·4H2O, it can be expected that both compounds have common structural features. X-ray crystallography revealed that 4·H2O has lower symmetry in space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit contains one silver cation, one bpp, one Hopa−, and half a guest water molecule (Figure a). Though as found in 3·4H2O, the Ag(I) atom displays a pseudo heavily distorted tetrahedral geometry connected by one Hopa− and two bpp ligands [Ag1−N = 2.248(2) and 2.239(2) Å], the coordination interactions between the metal centers and carboxylate groups are stronger in 4·H2O [Ag1−O = 2.478(2) and 2.637(2) Å].

Structure of [Ag2(R-Hopa)(S-Hopa)(bpp)2]⋅H2O (4⋅H2O)

As 4⋅H2O was yielded from the dehydration of 3⋅4H2O, it can be expected that both compounds have common structural features. X-ray crystallography revealed that 4⋅H2O has lower symmetry in space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit contains one silver cation, one bpp, one Hopa-, and half a guest water molecule (Figure a). Though as found in 3⋅4H2O, the Ag(I) atom displays a pseudo heavily distorted tetrahedral geometry connected by one Hopa- and two bpp ligands [Ag1-N = 2.248(2) and 2.239(2) Å], the coordination interactions between the metal centers and carboxylate groups are stronger in 4⋅H2O [Ag1-O = 2.478(2) and 2.637(2) Å].

elements.content: 1D [Ag(bpp)] n n+ along the b axis can still be found in 4·H2O. Nevertheless, the dehydration resulted in the loss of three-quarters of the guest water molecules and smaller void space between the layers. The hydrogen bonding helices formed between two Hopa− and four water molecules were therefore broken, leading to the moving of [Ag(bpp)] n n+ layers. The dimeric [Ag2(bpp)2]2+ units linked by weak Ag···Ag interactions in compounds 1−3 were dissociated and the closest Ag···Ag separation between the [Ag(bpp)] n n+ chains extends from 3.223(1) Å in 3·4H2O to 4.902 Å in 4·H2O (Figure b). Analogous to 3·4H2O, neighboring [Ag(bpp)] n n+ chains on the silver pyridine layer are centro-symmetric. R-Hopa− and S-Hopa− stretch alternatively on both sides of the layer and form hydrogen bonds through the hydroxyl and carboxylate groups between the layers [O3···O2 = 2.644(2) Å, O3−H3O···O2 = 118(2)°; O3···O2a = 2.976(2) Å, O3−H3O···O2a = 142(2)°] (Figure c). The lattice aqua molecules are situated in between the silver layers and have weak hydrogen interactions with the Hopa− carboxylate groups, as shown in Figure d [O1w···O1 = 2.744(4) Å, O1W−H1WA···O1 = 151.3°; O1W···O1b = 2.919(4) Å, O1W−H1WB···O1b = 151.9°].

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction showed that 5·2MeOH is isostructural to 3·4H2O, and single crystal X-ray diffraction revealed that 5·2MeOH has a very similar unit cell in the same space group of P21/c. Analogous Ag2(bpp)2 2+ dimer and 2D Ag-bpp layers can also be observed in 5·2MeOH (Figure a,b); however, the Ag···Ag distance within the silver dimeric unit contracts from 3.223(1) Å in 3·4H2O and 4.902 Å in 4·H2O to 2.921(1) Å. The silver atom is also in a heavily distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry and the interaction between Ag and the Hopa− carboxylate group is pretty weak [Ag1−N = 2.188(1) and 2.200(1) Å, Ag1−O = 2.644(2) and 2.745(1) Å].

Structure of [Ag2(R-Hopa)(S-Hopa)(bpp)2]⋅2MeOH (5⋅2MeOH)

Powder X-ray diffraction showed that 5⋅2MeOH is isostructural to 3⋅4H2O, and single crystal X-ray diffraction revealed that 5⋅2MeOH has a very similar unit cell in the same space group of P21/c. Analogous Ag2(bpp)2 2+ dimer and 2D Ag-bpp layers can also be observed in 5⋅2MeOH (Figure a,b); however, the Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag distance within the silver dimeric unit contracts from 3.223(1) Å in 3⋅4H2O and 4.902 Å in 4⋅H2O to 2.921(1) Å. The silver atom is also in a heavily distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry and the interaction between Ag and the Hopa- carboxylate group is pretty weak [Ag1-N = 2.188(1) and 2.200(1) Å, Ag1-O = 2.644(2) and 2.745(1) Å].

elements.content: Adjacent [Ag2(bpp)2] n 2n+ layers are interconnected by rac-Hopa− and MeOH into sandwich-like supramolecular network (Figure c). The hydrogen-bonded chain is composed of alternative R-Hopa−···MeOH and S-Hopa−···MeOH [O4···O2 = 2.739(5) Å, O4−H4o···O2 = 155°] (Figure d). The suitable size of the volume between the layers and the existence of hydroxyl group on Hopa− may account for the affinity of the framework for methanol.

The hydrogen-bonded chain is composed of alternative R-Hopa-⋅⋅⋅MeOH and S-Hopa-⋅⋅⋅MeOH [O4⋅⋅⋅O2 = 2.739(5) Å, O4-H4o⋅⋅⋅O2 = 155°] (Figure d). The suitable size of the volume between the layers and the existence of hydroxyl group on Hopa- may account for the affinity of the framework for methanol.

elements.content: Phase transformation based on flexible networks is one of the most interesting phenomena in coordination polymers though the understanding of their mechanisms is still a big challenge. The versatile hydrogen bonds between Hopa− and the lattice water or MeOH molecules are essential for the dynamic structural transformations among 3·4H2O, 4·H2O, and 5·2MeOH via partial dehydration, readsorption, and guest-exchange. The suitable size and the affinity for hydrogen bonds may account for the selective absorption of methanol in the mixed MeOH−EtOH−DMF solvent for 4·H2O. The exchange of the lattice methanol in 5·2MeOH to water in 4·H2O in wet air may be due to the easy volatility of methanol and greater affinity of aqua for hydrogen bonds. The dehydration and exchange of the guest molecules give rise to the breakage and reformation of hydrogen bonding chains, which leads to the reversible slipping movement of [Ag(bpp)] n n+ chains on the [Ag2(bpp)2] n 2n+ layers in these compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Phase Transformation Discussion

Phase transformation based on flexible networks is one of the most interesting phenomena in coordination polymers though the understanding of their mechanisms is still a big challenge. The versatile hydrogen bonds between Hopa- and the lattice water or MeOH molecules are essential for the dynamic structural transformations among 3⋅4H2O, 4⋅H2O, and 5⋅2MeOH via partial dehydration, readsorption, and guest-exchange. The suitable size and the affinity for hydrogen bonds may account for the selective absorption of methanol in the mixed MeOH-EtOH-DMF solvent for 4⋅H2O. The exchange of the lattice methanol in 5⋅2MeOH to water in 4⋅H2O in wet air may be due to the easy volatility of methanol and greater affinity of aqua for hydrogen bonds. The dehydration and exchange of the guest molecules give rise to the breakage and reformation of hydrogen bonding chains, which leads to the reversible slipping movement of [Ag(bpp)] n   n+ chains on the [Ag2(bpp)2] n  2n+ layers in these compounds.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis shows that 1−5 have similar thermal stability. The first weight loss at below 100 °C was observed for all the compounds, which is in accordance with the loss of lattice water or methanol molecules. The networks began to decompose at above 150 °C (Figure ). For 1·3H2O and 2·3H2O, the observed weight loss (5.35%) at 60 °C is corresponding to the removal of three guest water molecules (5.58%); for 3·4H2O, the release of four water molecules per formula was observed under 80 °C (observed 7.20%, calcd: 7.31%); for 4·H2O, the removal of one lattice water molecule (1.84%) occurred at 105 °C with the observed weight loss of 1.91%; for 5·2MeOH, two guest methanol molecules escaped from the network under 85 °C (observed 6.29%, calcd. 6.87%).

TGA Characterization

Thermogravimetric analysis shows that 1-5 have similar thermal stability. The first weight loss at below 100 °C was observed for all the compounds, which is in accordance with the loss of lattice water or methanol molecules. The networks began to decompose at above 150 °C (Figure ). For 1⋅3H2O and 2⋅3H2O, the observed weight loss (5.35%) at 60 °C is corresponding to the removal of three guest water molecules (5.58%); for 3⋅4H2O, the release of four water molecules per formula was observed under 80 °C (observed 7.20%, calcd: 7.31%); for 4⋅H2O, the removal of one lattice water molecule (1.84%) occurred at 105 °C with the observed weight loss of 1.91%; for 5⋅2MeOH, two guest methanol molecules escaped from the network under 85 °C (observed 6.29%, calcd. 6.87%).

The solid-state CD Spectra of 1·3H2O and 2·3H2O are given in Figure .

The bulky crystalline sample of 1·3H2O in a KCl pellet displays negative Cotton effects at the band of about 205−230 nm. And the CD signal of 2·3H2O sample is the mirror image of 1·3H2O. The results of CD measurements show the enantiopurity of 1·3H2O and 2·3H2O, confirming that H2opa keep their chirality under these reaction conditions.

Solid-state CD spectra

The solid-state CD Spectra of 1⋅3H2O and 2⋅3H2O are given in Figure .

The bulky crystalline sample of 1⋅3H2O in a KCl pellet displays negative Cotton effects at the band of about 205-230 nm. And the CD signal of 2⋅3H2O sample is the mirror image of 1⋅3H2O. The results of CD measurements show the enantiopurity of 1⋅3H2O and 2⋅3H2O, confirming that H2opa keep their chirality under these reaction conditions.

elements.content: Two enantiopure and one racemic Ag-bpp-Hopa− sandwich-like supramolecular networks, 1·3H2O, 2·3H2O, and 3·4H2O, have been prepared and characterized. All the compounds have analogous [Ag2(bpp)2] n 2n+ coordination layers connected by Hopa−−H2O hydrogen bonding chains. In 1·3H2O and 2·3H2O, R-Hopa− or S-Hopa− form left-handed or right-handed helices with water molecules running in parallel to the Ag-bpp layers while in 3·4H2O, the centrosymmetric hydrogen bonding chains are composed of two enantiomers of Hopa−.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Two enantiopure and one racemic Ag-bpp-Hopa- sandwich-like supramolecular networks, 1⋅3H2O, 2⋅3H2O, and 3⋅4H2O, have been prepared and characterized. All the compounds have analogous [Ag2(bpp)2] n  2n+ coordination layers connected by Hopa--H2O hydrogen bonding chains. In 1⋅3H2O and 2⋅3H2O, R-Hopa- or S-Hopa- form left-handed or right-handed helices with water molecules running in parallel to the Ag-bpp layers while in 3⋅4H2O, the centrosymmetric hydrogen bonding chains are composed of two enantiomers of Hopa-.

elements.content: Upon dehydration, readsorption and selective guest-exchange, reversible phase transformation of 3·4H2O was observed. The Ag···Ag dimeric units in [Ag2(bpp)2] n 2n+ in 3·4H2O were broken and new Hopa−−H2O chains between the silver layers were formed in 4·H2O by adjusting the positions of the Ag-bpp chains when there is less lattice aqua molecules. After absorbing methanol, the Ag-bpp chains restored to their original layer structures in 5·2MeOH. The different structural features can be ascribed to different hydrogen bonding interactions between Hopa− and the lattice water or MeOH molecules.
elements.clean_text: Upon dehydration, readsorption and selective guest-exchange, reversible phase transformation of 3⋅4H2O was observed. The Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag dimeric units in [Ag2(bpp)2] n  2n+ in 3⋅4H2O were broken and new Hopa--H2O chains between the silver layers were formed in 4⋅H2O by adjusting the positions of the Ag-bpp chains when there is less lattice aqua molecules. After absorbing methanol, the Ag-bpp chains restored to their original layer structures in 5⋅2MeOH. The different structural features can be ascribed to different hydrogen bonding interactions between Hopa- and the lattice water or MeOH molecules.

Excess aqueous NH3 solution was dropped slowly into a suspension of Ag2O (0.046 g, 0.2 mmol) in EtOH/H2O (15 mL, V/V = 1:1) with magnetically stirring for 15 min. R-H2opa (0.061 g, 0.4 mmol) and bpp (0.079 g, 0.4 mmol) were slowly added to the silver solution. The mixture was further vigorously stirred under heating at 50 °C for 2 h. The resulting solution was filtered and allowed to stand in air at room temperature. Block colorless crystals of 1·3H2O were obtained after four days (yields 0.068 g, ca. 35%). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C42H48O9N4Ag2: C, 52.08; H, 5.00; N, 5.78. Found: C, 51.93; H, 4.98; N, 5.75. IR data (KBr) (400−4000 cm−1): 3372(s), 3082(w), 2925(w), 2841(w), 1906(m), 1606(vs), 1575(s), 1496(m), 1451(w), 1391(m), 1258(m), 1221(w), 1187(m), 1025(s), 927(w), 840(m), 735(m), 714(m), 614(w), 511(m).

The procedure was similar to that used in the preparation of 1·3H2O except that S-H2opa (0.061 g, 0.4 mmol) was used. Small block colorless crystals of 2·3H2O were obtained after three days. (yields 0.077 g, ca. 40%). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C42H48O9N4Ag2: C, 52.08; H, 5.00; N, 5.78. Found: C, 51.89; H, 5.03; N, 5.89. Excess aqueous NH3 solution was dropped slowly into a suspension of Ag2O (0.046 g, 0.2 mmol) in EtOH/H2O (15 mL, V/V = 1:1) with magnetically stirring for 15 min. R-H2opa (0.061 g, 0.4 mmol) and bpp (0.079 g, 0.4 mmol) were slowly added to the silver solution. The mixture was further vigorously stirred under heating at 50 °C for 2 h. cln_elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis shows that 1−5 have similar thermal stability. The first weight loss at below 100 °C was observed for all the compounds, which is in accordance with the loss of lattice water or methanol molecules. The networks began to decompose at above 150 °C (Figure ). For 1·3H2O and 2·3H2O, the observed weight loss (5.35%) at 60 °C is corresponding to the removal of three guest water molecules (5.58%); for 3·4H2O, the release of four water molecules per formula was observed under 80 °C (observed 7.20%, calcd: 7.31%); for 4·H2O, the removal of one lattice water molecule (1.84%) occurred at 105 °C with the observed weight loss of 1.91%; for 5·2MeOH, two guest methanol molecules escaped from the network under 85 °C (observed 6.29%, calcd. 6.87%).

TGA Characterization

Thermogravimetric analysis shows that 1-5 have similar thermal stability. The first weight loss at below 100 °C was observed for all the compounds, which is in accordance with the loss of lattice water or methanol molecules. The networks began to decompose at above 150 °C (Figure ). For 1⋅3H2O and 2⋅3H2O, the observed weight loss (5.35%) at 60 °C is corresponding to the removal of three guest water molecules (5.58%); for 3⋅4H2O, the release of four water molecules per formula was observed under 80 °C (observed 7.20%, calcd: 7.31%); for 4⋅H2O, the removal of one lattice water molecule (1.84%) occurred at 105 °C with the observed weight loss of 1.91%; for 5⋅2MeOH, two guest methanol molecules escaped from the network under 85 °C (observed 6.29%, calcd. 6.87%).
